Develop a personalized productivity system: Create a customized system that addresses the root causes of your jealousy. This could involve breaking down tasks into manageable steps, prioritizing tasks based on importance and urgency, and implementing time-blocking to avoid multitasking and distractions. By tailoring your productivity system to your unique needs, you can optimize your workflow and reduce feelings of jealousy.

Embrace the "good enough" mindset: Recognize that perfection is subjective and that it's okay to produce "good enough" work. Comparing yourself to others can lead to feelings of inadequacy and jealousy. Instead, focus on your own progress and celebrate small victories along the way. By embracing the "good enough" mindset, you can reduce feelings of jealousy and cultivate a more positive attitude towards your work.

Practice gratitude and self-care: Take time each day to reflect on the things you're grateful for, including your own strengths and accomplishments. Engage in self-care activities that nourish your mind, body, and soul, such as meditation, exercise, or creative pursuits. By prioritizing self-care and cultivating a sense of gratitude, you can reduce feelings of jealousy and improve your overall well-being.

Set realistic expectations: Unrealistic expectations can lead to feelings of inadequacy and jealousy. Set achievable goals for yourself, and recognize that success is a journey rather than a destination. By setting realistic expectations, you can reduce feelings of jealousy and focus on your own progress and growth.

Seek support from like-minded individuals: Connect with others who share your passions and interests. By surrounding yourself with supportive peers, you can cultivate a sense of community and reduce feelings of isolation. This can involve joining online communities, attending workshops or conferences, or participating in local meetups. By seeking support from like-minded individuals, you can reduce feelings of jealousy and stay motivated to achieve your goals.
